content.text: Calculate the resultant vertical force and state its direction
resultant vertical force =   .........  N
direction
Suggest and explain what happens to the size of the upward vertical force on the parachute if the area of the parachute used is increased
suggestion
explanation
Fig. 1.1 shows **three** vertical forces acting on the box and the parachute
Determine the time when the speed of the box is \(30 \text{m / s}\)
Deduce the size of the resultant vertical force on the box when the time is 35s. Explain your answer
size of resultant vertical force
explanation
Calculate the distance the box moves between time = 30 s and time = 40 s
Fig. 1.2 shows the speed–time graph for the box before the parachute is opened
Fig. 1.1 shows a box attached to a parachute. The box and the parachute are falling through the air
Fig. 1.1
The driver applies a force of \(200\mathrm{N}\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
Calculate the moment of the \(200\mathrm{N}\) force about the centre of the wheel nut
moment of force =   .........  Ncm
The moment in **(a)** does not release the wheel nut. The driver **cannot** increase the force but can increase its moment
State and explain how the driver can increase the moment of the force
statement
explanation
The driver releases a second wheel nut in a shorter time than the first wheel nut. The driver uses the same amount of energy in releasing both wheel nuts
Complete the sentences using the phrases in the box. Each phrase may be used once, more than once or not at all
The work done in releasing the second wheel nut is ............................................ the work done in releasing the first wheel nut
The power produced in releasing the second wheel nut is ............................................ the power produced in releasing the first wheel nut
A car driver needs to remove one of the wheels on his car. He puts a spanner on a wheel nut
Determine the atmospheric pressure indicated by the barometer. Include the unit
State what is in the space labelled X above the mercury in the tube
The total weight of the mercury barometer is \(38 \text{N}\)
The area of the glass container in contact with the bench is \(200 \text{cm}^2\)
Calculate the pressure of the mercury barometer on the bench
pressure =   .........  N/cm²
Fig. 3.1 shows a mercury barometer
Describe the movement and arrangement of the gas molecules in the container
The gas in the container is heated. The volume of the gas does **not** change
State and explain the change in pressure of the gas as the temperature of the gas increases. Use your ideas about molecules in your answer
A rigid container is filled with a gas
Describe and explain how the water evaporates. Use your ideas about molecules
Evaporation changes the temperature of the water that remains in the beaker
State and explain the change in temperature of the water due to evaporation
A beaker contains water. Some of the water evaporates
The arrows in Fig. 6.1 show the directions in which air moves
Explain why the air moves as shown in Fig. 6.1
A student has four rods of identical size. The rods are made of copper, brass, iron and glass
Describe an experiment to compare thermal conduction along the rods
You may draw a labelled diagram to help with your answer
Fig. 6.1 shows equipment used to demonstrate convection in air. A burning candle is placed beneath glass tube A
Explain why the type of wave in Fig. 7.1 is a longitudinal wave
Measure the wavelength of the wave shown in Fig. 7.1
wavelength =   .........  \(cm\)
State what is meant by the frequency of a wave
The wave in Fig. 7.1 travels \(25 \text{cm}\) in \(0.20 \text{s}\)
Calculate the speed of the wave
A teacher uses a long spring to demonstrate wave motion. She makes a wave move along the coils of the spring
Fig. 7.1 shows the wave on the spring
Using Fig. 8.1, determine the distance of the object from the centre of the lens
distance =   .........  \(cm\)
On Fig. 8.2, draw an arrow to represent the focal length of the lens. Label this arrow f
Circle two words or phrases from those shown to describe the image formed in Fig. 8.2
enlarged upright inverted same size diminished
Fig. 8.2 shows another lens forming the image IY of object OP
Fig. 8.1 shows a converging lens and an object. The side of each square represents \(0.5 \text{cm}\)
Using the information in Table 9.1, draw a straight line from each sample to its correct property. Draw **three** lines
**sample** **property**
A magnetic and magnetised
B magnetic but not magnetised
C non-magnetic
Describe **one** method of producing a magnet from a bar of unmagnetised steel
Another student does an experiment with some electrostatically charged plastic rods
Fig. 9.2 shows the student's arrangement
Describe and explain what happens as the student brings one negatively charged rod close to the other negatively charged rod
A student tests whether a bar magnet affects three different materials
Fig. 9.1 shows the bar magnet and a sample of each material A, B and C
The student tests each sample by holding each pole of the magnet close to one end of the sample. Table 9.1 shows his observations

table.html:
sampleeffect of N poleeffect of S pole
Aattractionattraction
Bno effectno effect
Cattractionrepulsion

content.text: The kettle is switched on. There is a very large electric current in the live wire
Explain why this large electric current can be dangerous
Explain how a fuse helps to protect against the danger of a large electric current
Explain why the kettle is not safe to use with the fuse connected into the neutral wire instead of the live wire
The current in a device when operating normally is 3.1A
State a suitable value for the fuse
Choose **one** of these values: 3A, 5A, 10A and 13A
A small kettle has a potential difference (p.d.) of \(12\mathrm{V}\) (d.c.) across its heating element. The current in the heating element is 2.5A
Calculate the resistance of the heating element
resistance of the heating element =   .........  \(\Omega\)

Fig. 10.1 shows a metal kettle used for heating water. The kettle is connected to the mains power supply. The metal case is connected to earth. A fault causes the live wire to come loose and touch the metal case, as shown
Calculate the voltage across the secondary coil
voltage =   .........  V
State a suitable material for the core of the transformer
Some transformers produce high electrical voltage for the transmission of electrical energy. Describe two advantages of high-voltage transmission
Fig. 11.1 represents a transformer. The primary coil has 300 turns and the secondary coil has 30 turns. The input voltage is \(230\mathrm{Va.c.}\)
State one source of background radiation
Determine the half-life of the radioactive isotope. Use information from Fig. 12.1
Show on Fig. 12.1 how you obtained your value
half-life =   .........  minutes
The radioactive isotope emits \(\gamma\) -radiation
Describe **one** method of safely storing the radioactive isotope

Fig. 12.1 shows the graph of her results
A teacher is investigating radioactivity
The teacher measures the background radiation in the laboratory
